conclusion: Point charges at A and B both have charge Q > 0.
Point O is the midpoint of the horizontal line connecting A and B.
Point M is located vertically above O on the perpendicular bisector of AB, at a distance sqrt(2)L from O.
Point N is located vertically below O on the perpendicular bisector of AB, at a distance sqrt(2)L from O.
Distance between A and B is 2L, since O is the midpoint.
Distance from A to M (denoted R_M) is sqrt((L)^2 + (sqrt(2)L)^2) = sqrt(3)L.
Distance from B to M is also sqrt(3)L, due to symmetry.
The ball S_1 at M experiences forces due to the charges at A and B, given by F = kQq/R^2.
The force due to A is F_A = kQq/(sqrt(3)L)^2 = kQq/3L^2.
The force due to B is F_B = kQq/(sqrt(3)L)^2 = kQq/3L^2.
Force F_A points from M toward A and force F_B points from M toward B.
Horizontal components of F_A and F_B cancel each other due to symmetry, vertical components add up.
Vertical component of each force is given by F_vertical = F * cos(theta), where cos(theta) = sqrt(2)L/sqrt(3)L = sqrt(2)/sqrt(3).
Total vertical force at M is F_total, vertical = F_vertical, A + F_vertical, B = 2 * sqrt(2)kQq/(3sqrt(3)L^2).
Simplified expression for F_total, vertical is 2sqrt(2)kQq/(3sqrt(3)L^2).
